ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Actually so much knowlege! You understand why you are the way you are and the various psych processes you go through every day
The unconscious influence of the past, present, and future on our behavior and decision-making. I learned how to read research papers and engage with scientific literature.
I learned about unconscious influences.
very interesting cognitive science course that is an overall review of research on the unconscious
I learned a lot about cool psychology studies about unconscious processes.
Learned about many breakthrough psychological experiments from the past and also modern times.
I learned how to think about why I make certain judgements and how to avoid those innate judgemental qualities.
Learned a lot about how the unconscious mind worked!
A lot of interesting tidbits from different studies about different effects that our unconscious processes have on our daily lives.
just memorization
An appreciation for all the subtle influences on my goals, thoughts, behavior and so on. I think about things I've learned in this class at least a few times a week. Very insightful.
I learned a lot about the modern unconcsious
How the unconscious and conscious mind work together to make decisions

This course surveyed the unconscious influences that impact us in daily life- influences from the evolved human past, our personal past/childhood, the present, and our goals for the future. There was an overarching topic of unconscious motivation and goal pursuit. I thought it was excellent.

I learned about unconscious processes, in ways that I was able to connect to day-to-day life. We talked about how decisions and behavior are influenced by the past (carry-over from recent experiences, as well as older experiences), the present (situational triggers, mimicry of the actions of others, etc.), and the future (unconsciously held goals). One of my major takeaways is that the unconscious does a lot more than I'd realized, and so even when I think I'm making decisions fully consciously, there's a lot I'm not aware of.
Basically just learned a bunch of facts about studies and philosophical theories relating to the unconscious.
Learned about the history and theories of the unconscious mind, as well as many psychology experiments used as evidence.
the different levels of consciousness, heuristics, evolution of the mind, emotions

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The way the questions were worded on the exams was utterly terrible.

The lectures are great. Professor Bargh is incredibly engaging and knowledgeable about the topic. A weakness could be the organization of the course. The slides were disorganized and hard to follow especially if you are reading them without the lecture. The Canvas page was difficult to navigate due to the readings being filed in a non-uniform way.
I wish there were other assignments other than just exams.
there were only three exams, so it was not that much work. if you went to lecture and did all the readings, it wasn't hard to study and do well on the exams. very interesting course content.
To be honest the course was super interesting in the beginning but very repetitive towards the end.
The strength of this course is the content, which is super cool. The weaknesses are the slides, which are confusingly organized, making it harder to follow along in lecture.
I liked the chronological structure of the course, but many of the experiments overlapped and were reused between lectures.

Strengths - really interesting content; Exams are challenging but not too difficult; lectures do a good job of synthesizing / going back to previous lectures

Weaknesses - Recorded lectures would be nice in case of needing to miss class. A few other assignments or papers so our grades aren't just based on exams!

Terrible curve that is solely predicated on your peers performance, an 80 has traditionally been viewed as a B- in an uncurved class, but in this class, if all your peers do well you could end up with a grade much lower than that. Practice problems to prepare for the exams also wouldve helped a lot.

Formula for succeeding in the class is pretty simple. Go to class, take notes, and study those for the exams. From my own personal experience, if you are looking for an A in this class, you better take the best notes ever. Some questions on the test were things that went right by my head in lecture because things moved fast, and you can't miss much because everything is fair game for the test.
Boring and just memorizing so much

Strengths: interesting material
Weaknesses: not very engaging

The only three assignments are the three exams, with each one weighing more as the semester passes. This was a strength in that there wasn't any work to do throughout the semester, but you had to study really well for the exams. The weighting of the exams is unfair in that it puts the last exam at such a higher weight than the other two (almost 40% of your grade is the third exam that is at the end of the semester when we are all overrun with work for other classes). Prof. Bargh also lectures incredibly fast, and so it's hard to get down the notes that you need to for the exams.

Strength: covers a lot of material, non-accumulative midterms

Weakness: slides are not really organized and sometimes the class goes by too fast

It was a fascinating course and well-taught, although I think many students became frustrated at how it was graded-  on three non-cumulative exams and nothing else. Its important to have good study and test-taking skills for this class.
I found the lectures engaging, and I liked the readings. The reading load was manageable.
Strengths: material was often very interesting and engaging. Weaknesses: often presented in a boring, list-like way that did not invite critical thinking about the subject matter.

Strengths:
- Organized structure

Weaknesses:
- TAs
- Lecture clarity and speed
- Help after exams
really interesting content, prof is straightforward lecturer, definitely expert in his field, but the course has no room for student engagement

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! This course was so interesting and really well organized
No, course tests not on the understanding of concepts. The three exams are focused on random memorization and little tidbits.
Yes, this class was super manageable and the content I learned was super cool. You learn a lot about different psychological phenomena and why you do certain things you do!

Yes. This course is great for anyone as it helps you become more aware of the underlying reasons behind your behavior and decision-making. Beyond that, it serves as a great source of wonderful dinner conversations thanks to the fascinating studies and research papers.
Absolutely
Yes, it was very interesting!
No!!

Yes, I would recommend this course as long as you are confident in your test-taking abilities (or are planning to credit/D). Its a great class to learn about a bunch of cool psychology studies. The slides are somewhat cryptic and very disorganized, so attending lecture is a must in order to do well. Prof. Bargh is retiring though so it might be different with a new professor.
Yes - interesting to everyone even if you're not a psych major. My mind was consistently blown in almost every class! Very low workload.
Only if they like exam-heavy class grades and if they are willing to accept a terrible class curve.

Nah .. it was very interesting but very stressful to know that your grade relies on 3 tests that you don't necessarily know what to study except for class notes. If you are interested in the material, the information is very interesting. But Credit d for sure.
Yes if it were offered again.
No. Just memorizing psych facts. Tests were really hard
Yes - easy multiple choice exams, very interesting content.
I would only recommend this course to another student if they're really interested in the material.
Yes, if they are interested in learning about the human mind.
Yes! But unfortunately, Professor Bargh is retiring. I wish him well.

Yes, I would. I'm a STEM major, and this is the first psychology class I've taken, and I enjoyed it a lot. I learned a lot, and a lot of it felt applicable to my life, which I liked. The lectures were good, and so were the readings.
no. it was all based on exams where the questions often did not reflect the content learned in the class

I would not recommend this course to another student because I struggled to keep up while also understanding the material. Although I found the material interesting, I was stressed because there was so much hard material to understand with not enough time or explanation to do so.
yes definitely! teaches u so much about mental shortcuts and gives u a lot of tools to psychoanalyze yourself and others
